Award.AwardTitle: Targeted Infusion Project Grant: Incorporation of Sustainability Concepts into Undergraduate Civil Engineering Curriculum Using Project-Based Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Targeted Infusion Project - Incorporation of Sustainability Concepts into the Undergraduate Civil Engineering Curriculum Using Project-Based Learning - at North Carolina A&T State University (NCA&T) has the objective to enhance civil engineering students' knowledge about sustainability and its implications by incorporating concepts on sustainability into the undergraduate curriculum using a project-based learning approach. The specific objectives of the project are to create instructional materials related to sustainable development, to incorporate the contents into a three-course sequence in the civil engineering curriculum for undergraduates, and to evaluate the impact of this intervention on students' learning outcomes.

This project incorporates concepts on sustainability into the undergraduate curriculum by creating a three-course sequence from existing courses in the civil engineering curriculum while transforming these courses from lecture-based to project-based. To successfully introduce topics related to sustainability, theoretical concepts and hands-on projects will be implemented simultaneously. In this study transportation was selected because of the comprehensive, broad and tangible nature of the transportation field as well as the significant implications of sustainability in the transportation sector. Based on the theory of constructivism (a theory of learning which states that by reflecting on our experiences, we construct our own understanding of the world), transportation was deemed to be appropriate due to the daily interaction and personal experiences of students with aspects of transportation systems. As a result of the implementation of this intervention, students will be able to understand the basic philosophy and the importance of incorporating concepts on sustainability into their activities in future design, construction and maintenance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this Targeted Infusion Project wad to use project-based learning (PBL) approach to enhance engineering students’ learning outcomes as related to sustainability concepts and their implications. To achieve this objective, concepts related to sustainability were incorporated via PBL approach into three courses in undergraduate Civil Engineering under Transportation discipline. 

TAs part of the project, a three-course cohort was fully developed and taught several times. After each implementation, extensive data was collected from participating students by administering LITEE (http://www.litee.org/site) instrument. The reliability of the survey has been documented via tests performed by multiple institutions. Based on the survey results, the impact of applying PBL on students learning outcomes was examined. 

As part of the project we established a collaboration with Aalborg University of Denmark, which has a strong track record of applying PBL in their courses campus wide. Acknowledging that the effectiveness of PBL varies in each course as well as challenges related to applying PBL in lower level courses, we worked closely with Aalborg University to best address variability.

 

Specific project findings were pertaining to the effectiveness of PBL method on students learning outcomes. Improvements in students’ learning outcomes (higher order cognitive skills, self-efficacy, ease of learning subject matter, teamwork, and communication skills) as well as students’ level of achievement in two specific ABET outcomes related to students’ knowledge of contemporary issues (outcome j) and their skills in applying modern engineering tools (outcome k) were observed. It was found that PBL application significantly enhanced students’ higher order cognitive domain of learning. Another significant finding was identifying a noticeable reduction in standard deviation in attributes such as higher order cognitive domain of learning; this may suggest that our intervention could address students’ different learning styles equally well.
